pullRequest.body:
- Add versions for when the endpoints are `Nat` (for convenience).
- Add limit versions for when the endpoint tends to infinity.
- Add summability criteria using Abel summation


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [eeea6131a6](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19942/commits/eeea6131a6081047914f5d0398b5b536a557f9d5)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +4.33% | `Mathlib.NumberTheory.AbelSummation` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.NumberTheory.AbelSummation | 1988 | 2074 | +86 (+4.33%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.AbelSummation`|86|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Order.IsLocallyClosed` (new file)|635|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ _root_.sum_mul_eq_sub_sub_integral_mul'`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Icc`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Ici`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Ico`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Iic`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Iio`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Ioc`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Ioi`
`+ isLocallyClosed_Ioo`
`+ sum_mul_eq_sub_integral_mul₀`
`+ sum_mul_eq_sub_integral_mul₀'`
`+ summable_mul_of_bigO_atTop`
`+ summable_mul_of_bigO_atTop'`
`+ summable_of_sum_range_norm_le`
`+ tendsto_sum_mul_atTop_nhds_one_sub_integral`
`+ tendsto_sum_mul_atTop_nhds_one_sub_integral₀`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Question for reviewers: some results are stated in the case `c 0 = 0` but still, in this case, the statements contain terms like  `∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊b⌋₊, f k * c k` even though the term `k = 0` does contribute to the sum.

It is better to leave it like that for consistency (and the user can remove the term `k  = 0` latter on if needed) or should I changed the statements so that summations start at `1`?

> Question for reviewers: some results are stated in the case `c 0 = 0` but still, in this case, the statements contain terms like `∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊b⌋₊, f k * c k` even though the term `k = 0` does contribute to the sum.
> 
> It is better to leave it like that for consistency (and the user can remove the term `k = 0` latter on if needed) or should I changed the statements so that summations start at `1`?

I would say it is probably fine to leave it as it is for now. If it turns out that it would be convenient to have modified versions, they can still be added or changed.

> > Question for reviewers: some results are stated in the case `c 0 = 0` but still, in this case, the statements contain terms like `∑ k ∈ Icc 0 ⌊b⌋₊, f k * c k` even though the term `k = 0` does contribute to the sum.
> > It is better to leave it like that for consistency (and the user can remove the term `k = 0` latter on if needed) or should I changed the statements so that summations start at `1`?
> 
> I would say it is probably fine to leave it as it is for now. If it turns out that it would be convenient to have modified versions, they can still be added or changed.

Ok, thanks for your advice and the review.
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

```suggestion
theorem tendsto_sum_mul_atTop_nhds_one_sub_integral (hf_diff : ∀ t ∈ Set.Ici 0, DifferentiableAt ℝ f t)
```
There is no equality in the statement. Same for the next theorem.
The inlined tactic proof is a bit hard to parse, but with `refine Tendsto.congr' ?_ ?_` one gets an error message. Not sure how to improve this...
I added another `have` before so that things get easier to parse hopefully.

This proof is repeated essentially verbatim. Would it be possible to state a common generalization (e.g., working with `Ici k` and `c j = 0` for all `j < k` for arbitrary natural `k`) and then specialize it for the two relevant cases?
Indeed. I moved the common parts into two auxiliary lemmas.
I don't think `hc` is really necessary for the statement: without it, `h_bdd` and `hg₁` are only stronger, and the summability result is unaffected by having one additional term.

pullRequest.title: feat(NumberTheory/AbelSummation): add more results
